question.instruction: Select the correct answer and click Submit.

Options.Option: 31 years old
Gravida 5, 1 full-term, 1 preterm (34 weeks), 2 spontaneous abortions, and two live births
Obese
Type 2 diabetes – controlled with oral diabetes medication and diet
Good prenatal care
Presented in labor
Group B streptococcus (GBS) negative
Spontaneous Rupture of Membranes (SROM) at delivery – fluid clear
Vacuum assist with 2 pop-offs
Apgar scores: 5 (at 1 minute), 6 (at 5 minutes), 8 (at 10 minutes)
Required CPAP for several minutes in the delivery room

question.instruction: Select the correct answer and click Submit.

Options.Option: Normal
Abnormal

OptionHeader.QuestionDesc:
Which of the following would you consider risk factors that could negatively impact her fetus?
Select all that apply and click the submit button.

question.instruction: Select the correct answer and click Submit.

Options.Option: 20 years old
Temperature at time of admission 99.3°F (37.4°C)
Gravida 1, para 0 (first pregnancy)
Good prenatal care
At 34-weeks gestation, develops right upper quadrant abdominal pain, headache, and visual changes
Blood pressure 185/110
Protein is measured in her urine
Admitted to labor/delivery unit with a diagnosis of preeclampsia with severe features
Assessment of fetal heart tones and fetal movement reassuring
Infusion of magnesium sulfate started
Fetal ultrasound shows intrauterine growth restriction (estimated fetal weight < 10th percentile)

OptionHeader.QuestionDesc:
Which of the following would you consider risk factors that could negatively impact her fetus?
Select all that apply and click the submit button.

question.instruction: Select the correct answer and click Submit.

Options.Option: Two days after admission, maternal symptoms worsen and the mother is diagnosed with HELLP (hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets)
Antenatal corticosteroid dosing completed before delivery
Group B streptococcus screening negative
Cesarean section accomplished for maternal indications
Artificial rupture of membranes (AROM) at delivery – fluid clear
Apgar scores: 3 (at 1 minute), 8 (at 5 minutes)
Resuscitation: Dried, stimulated, poor respiratory effort so given positive pressure ventilation (PPV) for several minutes in the delivery room, then transitioned to CPAP
On room air with no CPAP required by 10 minutes of age
Held skin-to-skin briefly by the mother
Transferred to the Special Care Nursery at 15 minutes of age
